posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked:
Hey CD community,

Started up our limelight for the first time and MegaTag 2 (green) seems to be behaving erraticly. I’ll show a picture to explain.

Any tips?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Does this help?

Limelight 2 MegaTag2 issue: Robot stuck in the center of the field Java

link_counts.title: Limelight 2 MegaTag2 issue: Robot stuck in the center of the field

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: Thank you for the quick response. For the life of me thought I can’t find that setting. Where is it specifically?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
From the LimelightHelpers.java:

It appears that MegaTag2 has some but incomplete filtering of nonsense that we can tell it about the robot rotation. Sometimes impossible poses are sent to the center of the field. Sometimes LL can “see through” tags as if they are mounted 180 degrees from the actual mounting. and act according to that misinformation.

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: It seems that we are having the problem of it “seeing through it”. Is this fixable? Or do I need to run with MT1

posts.name: Roman Hernandez Sosa
posts.cooked:
I was having a similar problem, from what i know, mt2 takes reference from your gyro rotation to give a pose estimate, so if your gyro starts in a weird rotation it may return an incorrect position, this is our code to set the orientation of it

The way i solved it was by just determining which way is the front of your robot, in your case, since the robot is inverted, you would need to reset the gyroscope to align with your front

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: We got it kind of working, we ended up adding 185 to the gyro and it works now

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure what your setup for testing is but what I meant about MegaTag2 seeing through tags is if you give MegaTag2 an impossible geometry it has a couple of different “failures” but it isn’t MegaTag2 that failed it is your failure to give MegaTag2 the correct robot orientation for the tag in view.

Specifically what you did in your example is show the LL tag 13 which is mostly pointing downfield. Then you said the robot is also pointing downfield (default if you don’t tell it anything). The robot cannot in reality see a tag that is facing away from it because the tag is mounted on an opaque carrier. It’s all impossible but MegaTag2 didn’t fully validate that you tried something that cannot happen on a real robot on a real field - it appeared to see through the back of the tag instead of throwing some other error to indicate impossibility.

Yes, if the gyro fails then you can’t use MegaTag2 but that is an extremely rare condition and if you care to worry about it, you can have a backup gyro or have a backup pose determine such as MegaTag1. My team does not use a second gyro and we haven’t had any gyro problems.

Another pose failure manifest from an impossible geometry is setting the pose to the center of the field.

This is an excellent example of the old saying Garbage In - Garbage Out. Maybe LL should have a better error response but again - it doesn’t happen on real robots and real fields.

Edit if you meant you mounted or set the angle wrong on your gyro then that creates the same impossible geometry. The gyro has to point the same way as the WPILib standard - 0 is blue pointing at red.
